text: you're watching a 3d printer create a
polymer jellyfish it looks weird right
the printers nozzle is moving through
the jiggly medium as if it were water
but the material making up the jellyfish
stays put so how is that jelly stay in a
float the answer appropriately enough is
a gel a newly developed granular
hydrogel tommy Angelini of the
university of florida who love this
research explains we are simply creating
three-dimensional shapes out of
completely unattached fluid dispersed
particles
it's the granular gel that they're left
in that preserves the structure that you
make the granules Angela you spoke of
are microscopic particles of a
commercial copolymer that Co polymer
accounts for less than 1% of the mass of
the gel but the grains are still able to
hold the printed material in place the
rest of the hydrogel is mostly water and
that helps the printers nozzles slide
through the material almost as if it
weren't there
once the printers nozzle moves to the
material the hydrogel is able to flow
back into place and self-heal the long
shaft of the writing tip has to go back
and forth and back and forth and churn
through all of the material like
thousands of times any method that
relies on an embedding material that
doesn't allow for rapid self-healing
will never be able to achieve the kind
of large-scale homogeneity and precision
and control that we can achieve with a
granular gel medium
